tossups.question: The 34th ruling of the Synod of Elvira banned the daytime use of these objects in a cemetery. The rainy season in the Thai city of Ubon Ratchathani ("oo-bon rat-cha-tah-nee") is marked by a parade of these objects to the local Buddhist temple. The Root tantra inspired the Tibetan Buddhist practice of making these objects out of butter. In Eastern Christianity, the dikirion ("DIH-kee-ree-ohn") and trikirion ("TRIH-kee-ree-ohn") are ceremonial items used alongside these objects. The kinara uses seven of these objects to represent the principles of Kwanzaa. Jewish women wave their hands over (*) two of these objects before covering their eyes and blessing them at the onset of Shabbat. The shammash is the utilitarian 9th of these objects in a common Jewish usage. In Christian churches, the largest of these objects is usually the Paschal variety. For 10 points, name these objects held by a Menorah.
tossups.question_sanitized: The 34th ruling of the Synod of Elvira banned the daytime use of these objects in a cemetery. The rainy season in the Thai city of Ubon Ratchathani ("oo-bon rat-cha-tah-nee") is marked by a parade of these objects to the local Buddhist temple. The Root tantra inspired the Tibetan Buddhist practice of making these objects out of butter. In Eastern Christianity, the dikirion ("DIH-kee-ree-ohn") and trikirion ("TRIH-kee-ree-ohn") are ceremonial items used alongside these objects. The kinara uses seven of these objects to represent the principles of Kwanzaa. Jewish women wave their hands over (*) two of these objects before covering their eyes and blessing them at the onset of Shabbat. The shammash is the utilitarian 9th of these objects in a common Jewish usage. In Christian churches, the largest of these objects is usually the Paschal variety. For 10 points, name these objects held by a Menorah.
tossups.answer_sanitized: candles [accept candlesticks]

tossups.answer: sugars [accept monosaccharides, disaccharides, polysaccharides, or glycans; prompt on carbohydrates, glycoproteins, or N-linked or O-linked glycosylation]

tossups.answer_sanitized: Casper the Friendly Ghost

tossups.question: During this president's administration, the Hatch Act was passed to limit political activities by federal employees. A bill signed by this president provided for the construction of a nitrate processing plant at Muscle Shoals. That bill signed by this president called for improving the economic and social well-being of people in its namesake (*) region. An agency established by this president is still the largest energy utility in the American South and is called the Tennessee Valley Authority. This president's sweeping economic program to recover from the Great Depression was called the New Deal. For 10 points, name this four-term US President who served until the last days of World War II.
tossups.question_sanitized: During this president's administration, the Hatch Act was passed to limit political activities by federal employees. A bill signed by this president provided for the construction of a nitrate processing plant at Muscle Shoals. An agency established by this president is still the largest energy utility in the American South and is called the Tennessee Valley Authority. This president's sweeping economic program to recover from the Great Depression was called the New Deal. For 10 points, name this four-term US President who served until the last days of World War II.
tossups.answer_sanitized: Franklin Delano Roosevelt [or FDR; prompt on Roosevelt]

tossups.answer_sanitized: Mars

parts: This Caribbean nation consumes almost 355 kilograms of fruit per person per year and supplies more than a kilo per person per day, as a result of its large banana industry. Former prime ministers Eugenia Charles and Edison James have sought to diversify its economy.

This African country, known as the “land of a thousand hills,” has often led the world in per capita fruit production. This small East African nation has fertile soil along its coast on Lake Kivu, partly as a result of the volcanoes which form its border with the DRC.
Bizarrely, this European micronation on the Moselle, known as the Gibraltar of the North, is the world’s largest per capita producer of oranges.

parts: Name this constant, the base of the natural logarithm.

e can be represented as the continued fraction 2, 1, 2, 1, 1, 4, 1, 1, 6, etcetera, which is far less elegant than the expression of this number using only ones. The properties of this number’s recursive continued fraction have led many to call it the “most irrational” number.

The continued fraction for e, phi, and countless others can be listened to as musical notes, visualized as graphs, and compared with one another on this website, which originated as a collection of notecards owned by Neil Sloane.

The continued fraction for e, phi, and countless others can be listened to as musical notes, visualized as graphs, and compared with one another on this website, which originated as a collection of notecards owned by Neil Sloane.

Description acceptable. South Australia was dominated by the Liberal and Country League because of one of these systems started by Sir Thomas Playford. The original system of this kind was satirized in a cartoon depicting a certain amphibian.

The giant prankster Lange Wapper ("LAHN-guh VAH-pur") is a comic figure in the folklore of this country. Lange Wapper and the villainous giant Druon Antigoon ("DROO-uhn AN-tuh-goo-in") are both from this country’s city of Antwerp.

In a story narrated by Uncle Remus, a fox uses a “tar-baby” to aggravate this wily trickster. This subject of many stories by Joel Chandler Harris was voiced by Johnny Lee in the Disney film Song of the South.
parts_sanitized: What is the name of this prankster from Ostropol? This stock figure in Jewish comedy is the subject of illustrated books by Eric Kimmer.

The giant prankster Lange Wapper ("LAHN-guh VAH-pur") is a comic figure in the folklore of this country. Lange Wapper and the villainous giant Druon Antigoon ("DROO-uhn AN-tuh-goo-in") are both from this country’s city of Antwerp.

In a story narrated by Uncle Remus, a fox uses a “tar-baby” to aggravate this wily trickster. This subject of many stories by Joel Chandler Harris was voiced by Johnny Lee in the Disney film Song of the South.

bonuses.leadin: William Chester Minor apparently branded the face of a deserter with a letter D following this battle. For 10 points each:
bonuses.leadin_sanitized: William Chester Minor apparently branded the face of a deserter with a letter D following this battle. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Civil War battle of 1864, a bloody stalemate fought by Grant and Meade at the start of the Overland campaign.

After the Civil War, a murder in Lambeth, and imprisonment in Broadmoor for insanity, William Chester Minor produced his most famous work on this project. James Murray and Herbert Coleridge both led this extensive philological project at various points.

This English author contributed definitions for the Oxford English dictionary in the range near the word "waggle" including most famously for the word "walrus". This man is credited with popularizing the words orc and mithril which now appear in the dictionary.

parts: Identify this character. This woman lives alone in the decaying Satis House.
Miss Havisham appears in this novel by Charles Dickens, which concerns the life of Philip Pirrip.
Charles Dickens wrote a revised ending for Great Expectations on the advice of what other author? This author told Dickens that the original ending was too sad.
